article.headline: Oklahoma State 90, Detroit 56
article.story: STILLWATER, Okla. (AP) -- When David Monds began the season at Oklahoma State, he couldn't figure out where he belonged on the team. After a double-figure performance in his first start Tuesday night, Monds has found his place as one of the team's leaders. "Going from being on the bench to a leader on this team is a hard transition," Monds said after the Cowboys beat Detroit (1-2) 90-56 in the Las Vegas Holiday Invitational. "It was hard at first, but now I feel like I am becoming a leader." Monds, who finished with 13, helped Oklahoma State (3-0) extend its lead in the first half. After being fouled on a layup, he converted the three-point play with a free throw. Following a Detroit turnover on the ensuing possession, Monds sank a jump shot. He finished with 9 points in the first half, which was dominated by JamesOn Curry, who finished with 16. Curry provided an early spark for Oklahoma State, connecting on a three-point basket and a jumper on back-to-back possessions to give the Cowboys an 8-to-0 lead with 17:11 to play. He followed another three-point basket with a jump shot, stretching the Oklahoma State lead to 21-6 with 12:51 remaining in the half. The Cowboys never looked back. Head coach-designate Sean Sutton said many view Curry as a shooter, but he's also a playmaker. "He has always been an unselfish player," Sutton said. "He takes good shots and passing is something he enjoys doing." Oklahoma also got help from Torre Johnson, whose two-hand jam at the 6:44 mark widened the Cowboys' lead to 35-13, and Terrel Harris, who hit a 3-pointer as the halftime buzzer sounded to expand the lead to 50-23. Johnson finished with 15 points. Mario Boggan scored 14 and Monds added 13 in the victory. Oklahoma State maintained its lead in the second half, although a lay-in by senior guard Ben Green moved the Titans to within 61-45 with 12:28 remaining. Green finished with 9 points and Brandon Cotton paced Detroit with 18 points. A steal and back-to-back lay-ins helped the Cowboys surge back ahead by 20. Oklahoma State converted on 32-of-53 field goals in the game, including 7-of-10 from three-point range. The Cowboys committed just 8 turnovers. Sutton attributed Oklahoma State's success to its ability to stick with the game plan. "We executed our offense in the half court a lot better than we've been doing," Sutton said.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
